pull_request.title: JavaScript runs once, CSS handles a 24 hour animation
pull_request.body:
Somewhere between an interesting experiment and something I wanted to do. No hard feelings if you do not deem it mergable, I will just continue on my fork. There is probably more clean-up that can be done.

This change gets rid of the 4 second JavaScript interval. Instead it generates 24 hour CSS animations once and lets the browser handle it. In the browser profiler this gets rid of rendering and painting steps.

Currently all the elements are added by JavaScript and the animations generated on the fly. Though for even better performance it could have been added straight to the HTML. The only thing JavaScript will always be needed for is to set the animation start time.

This also simplifies the blue hover styling. No more weird blinking in and out of existence for the final coloured rectangle.

Would love to get your opinion on some of these techniques!

issue.title: Define "normalized absolute URL"
issue.body:
This issue is split from https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9 intended to focus only on the process of normalizing URLs when parsing `u-*`.

[Current language](https://microformats.org/wiki/microformats2-parsing#parsing_a_u-_property): 
> return the normalized absolute URL of the gotten value, following the containing document's language's rules for resolving relative URLs (e.g. in HTML, use the current URL context as determined by the page, and first `<base>` element, if any).

One of the simplest things, which https://github.com/microformats/tests/pull/112 is waiting on, is whether to normalize an empty URL path component to "/". @jgarber623 [detailed](https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9#issuecomment-617813565) some specs and software that include this normalization, so I think this would be pretty agreeable among implementers.

@Zegnat raised the concern of defining what we mean by "path component" since parts of URLs have been [renamed over the years](https://tantek.com/2011/238/b1/many-ways-slice-url-name-pieces#ud). The [IndieAuth spec](https://indieauth.spec.indieweb.org/#url-canonicalization-p-3) includes a normative reference to WHATWG's URL standard and explains "path component" with a simple example instead of a spec definition:

> As such, if a URL with no path component is ever encountered, it MUST be treated as if it had the path /. For example, if a user provides https://example.com for Discovery, the client MUST transform it to https://example.com/ when using it and comparing it.

So perhaps that would be sufficient for the microformats parsing spec, too?

RFC 3986 lists some [additional normalizations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-6.2) that could be nice-to-have but I'm not sure if they are strictly necessary for parsers:
- make scheme and hostname lowercase
- normalize percent-encoded characters to uppercase ("%3a" versus "%3A")
- decode percent-encoded [unreserved characters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.3)

RFC 3986 also describes [remove_dot_segments](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-5.2.4) to normalize "." and ".." path segments. From a quick check, it appears at least php-mf2, mf2py, and Ruby parsers are all doing this, which makes sense since it's necessary to correclty handle `<base href>`.

**Questions:**
1. Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?
2. What are the simplest steps for this process such that it results in "a) easy for implementers to understand and b) leads to a useful output for consumers" (to quote @Zegnat :))

comment.body: Are paths always `/` if not empty? Even for non-HTTP URLs? IndieAuth is able to short-cut this somewhat as all URLs (except redirect URLs in special cases) are Special URLs, that is, HTTP(S) URLs.

issue.title: Define "normalized absolute URL"
issue.body:
This issue is split from https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9 intended to focus only on the process of normalizing URLs when parsing `u-*`.

[Current language](https://microformats.org/wiki/microformats2-parsing#parsing_a_u-_property): 
> return the normalized absolute URL of the gotten value, following the containing document's language's rules for resolving relative URLs (e.g. in HTML, use the current URL context as determined by the page, and first `<base>` element, if any).

One of the simplest things, which https://github.com/microformats/tests/pull/112 is waiting on, is whether to normalize an empty URL path component to "/". @jgarber623 [detailed](https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9#issuecomment-617813565) some specs and software that include this normalization, so I think this would be pretty agreeable among implementers.

@Zegnat raised the concern of defining what we mean by "path component" since parts of URLs have been [renamed over the years](https://tantek.com/2011/238/b1/many-ways-slice-url-name-pieces#ud). The [IndieAuth spec](https://indieauth.spec.indieweb.org/#url-canonicalization-p-3) includes a normative reference to WHATWG's URL standard and explains "path component" with a simple example instead of a spec definition:

> As such, if a URL with no path component is ever encountered, it MUST be treated as if it had the path /. For example, if a user provides https://example.com for Discovery, the client MUST transform it to https://example.com/ when using it and comparing it.

So perhaps that would be sufficient for the microformats parsing spec, too?

RFC 3986 lists some [additional normalizations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-6.2) that could be nice-to-have but I'm not sure if they are strictly necessary for parsers:
- make scheme and hostname lowercase
- normalize percent-encoded characters to uppercase ("%3a" versus "%3A")
- decode percent-encoded [unreserved characters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.3)

RFC 3986 also describes [remove_dot_segments](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-5.2.4) to normalize "." and ".." path segments. From a quick check, it appears at least php-mf2, mf2py, and Ruby parsers are all doing this, which makes sense since it's necessary to correclty handle `<base href>`.

**Questions:**
1. Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?
2. What are the simplest steps for this process such that it results in "a) easy for implementers to understand and b) leads to a useful output for consumers" (to quote @Zegnat :))

comment.body:
> Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?

I strongly feel like it is normali[sz]ation. Just like how RFC 3986 refers to it. Canonicali[sz]ation to me refers to what [rel-canonical](https://microformats.org/wiki/rel-canonical) is used for, matching the definition from Wikipedia:

> A canonical URL is a URL for defining the single source of truth for duplicate content.

There is no way for a parser like the mf2 parser to figure out that value, since it only has the string to work on. (I would be very much opposed to requiring mf2 parsers to fetch resources, look for [rel-canonical](https://microformats.org/wiki/rel-canonical)s, etc.)

issue.title: Add ARM download URL to mutesync.app cask
issue.body:
After installing with the old cask definition, starting the application showed me a pop-up telling me they had released a separate version for M1/M2 Macs. This updates the cask definition to grab the separate DMGs for ARM and Intel.

I found two different ways casks were doing this. Either by setting an `arch` variable that is used within the download URL, or using the `on_` blocks. I went with the latter as I thought an empty string variable for the Intel URL would just be confusing for the next person to read this definition.

---

After making all changes to a cask, verify:

- [x] The submission is for [a stable version](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#stable-versions) or [documented exception](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#but-there-is-no-stable-version).
- [x] `brew audit --cask --online <cask>` is error-free.
- [x] `brew style --fix <cask>` reports no offenses.

commits.message: Use arch variable in mutesync.app cask

pull_request.title: Add ARM download URL to mutesync.app cask
pull_request.body:
After installing with the old cask definition, starting the application showed me a pop-up telling me they had released a separate version for M1/M2 Macs. This updates the cask definition to grab the separate DMGs for ARM and Intel.

I found two different ways casks were doing this. Either by setting an `arch` variable that is used within the download URL, or using the `on_` blocks. I went with the latter as I thought an empty string variable for the Intel URL would just be confusing for the next person to read this definition.

---

After making all changes to a cask, verify:

- [x] The submission is for [a stable version](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#stable-versions) or [documented exception](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#but-there-is-no-stable-version).
- [x] `brew audit --cask --online <cask>` is error-free.
- [x] `brew style --fix <cask>` reports no offenses.

issue.title: Fix for Composer installation
issue.body:
When `humbug/box` is installed via Composer then
```php
require_once __DIR__.'/../vendor/composer/InstalledVersions.php';
```
(from https://github.com/box-project/box/blob/4.0.2/src/functions.php#L61)

fails as this files exist only when is used as PHAR.

Current behaviour can be seen in the failing check in https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/PHP-CS-Fixer/pull/6554.

comment.body:
In waiting for this PR, I have been able to apply it through [cweagans/composer-patches](https://github.com/cweagans/composer-patches). Installation instructions from scratch:

```zsh
composer config --no-plugins allow-plugins.bamarni/composer-bin-plugin true
composer require --dev bamarni/composer-bin-plugin
composer bin box config allow-plugins.cweagans/composer-patches true
composer bin box require --dev cweagans/composer-patches
composer bin box config --json extra.patches '{ "humbug/box": { "Fix for Composer installation": "https://github.com/box-project/box/pull/695.patch" } }'
composer bin box require --dev humbug/box
```

issue.title: Composer installation does not work when following docs
issue.body:
## Bug report

| Question    | Answer
| ------------| ---------------
| Box version | 4.0.2 (`composer bin all show \| grep humbug/box`)
| PHP version | 8.1.10
| Composer version | 2.4.1
| Platform with version | macOS 12.5.1

Running `vendor/bin/box` will throw an Exception and the application cannot be used after following [the Installation documentation for Composer](https://box-project.github.io/box/installation/#composer).

Quick reproduction steps:
```bash
# Clean folder and composer.json
cd `mktemp -d -t 'box'`
composer init --no-interaction --name zegnat/test
composer config allow-plugins.bamarni/composer-bin-plugin true
# Recommended installation steps
composer require --dev bamarni/composer-bin-plugin
composer bin box require --dev humbug/box
```

<details>
 <summary>Output</summary>
 
 ```bash
bash-5.1$ vendor/bin/box
PHP Fatal error:  Uncaught ErrorException: require_once(/private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/../vendor/composer/InstalledVersions.php): Failed to open stream: No such file or directory in /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php:61
Stack trace:
#0 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php(61): KevinGH\Box\{closure}(2, 'require_once(/p...', '/private/var/fo...', 61)
#1 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php(61): require_once()
#2 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/Console/Application.php(40): KevinGH\Box\get_box_version()
#3 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/bin/box(58): KevinGH\Box\Console\Application->__construct()
#4 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor/bin/box(120): include('/private/var/fo...')
#5 {main}
  thrown in /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php on line 61

Fatal error: Uncaught ErrorException: require_once(/private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/../vendor/composer/InstalledVersions.php): Failed to open stream: No such file or directory in /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php:61
Stack trace:
#0 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php(61): KevinGH\Box\{closure}(2, 'require_once(/p...', '/private/var/fo...', 61)
#1 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php(61): require_once()
#2 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/Console/Application.php(40): KevinGH\Box\get_box_version()
#3 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/bin/box(58): KevinGH\Box\Console\Application->__construct()
#4 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor/bin/box(120): include('/private/var/fo...')
#5 {main}
  thrown in /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php on line 61
 ```
</details>

comment.body:
Just realised there is already a PR for: https://github.com/box-project/box/pull/695. But I could not find an issue?

Feel free to close this in favour of the PR, or keep it around until the PR gets merged so others have an easier time finding it.

pull_request.title: JavaScript runs once, CSS handles a 24 hour animation
pull_request.body:
Somewhere between an interesting experiment and something I wanted to do. No hard feelings if you do not deem it mergable, I will just continue on my fork. There is probably more clean-up that can be done.

This change gets rid of the 4 second JavaScript interval. Instead it generates 24 hour CSS animations once and lets the browser handle it. In the browser profiler this gets rid of rendering and painting steps.

Currently all the elements are added by JavaScript and the animations generated on the fly. Though for even better performance it could have been added straight to the HTML. The only thing JavaScript will always be needed for is to set the animation start time.

This also simplifies the blue hover styling. No more weird blinking in and out of existence for the final coloured rectangle.

Would love to get your opinion on some of these techniques!

issue.title: Define "normalized absolute URL"
issue.body:
This issue is split from https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9 intended to focus only on the process of normalizing URLs when parsing `u-*`.

[Current language](https://microformats.org/wiki/microformats2-parsing#parsing_a_u-_property): 
> return the normalized absolute URL of the gotten value, following the containing document's language's rules for resolving relative URLs (e.g. in HTML, use the current URL context as determined by the page, and first `<base>` element, if any).

One of the simplest things, which https://github.com/microformats/tests/pull/112 is waiting on, is whether to normalize an empty URL path component to "/". @jgarber623 [detailed](https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9#issuecomment-617813565) some specs and software that include this normalization, so I think this would be pretty agreeable among implementers.

@Zegnat raised the concern of defining what we mean by "path component" since parts of URLs have been [renamed over the years](https://tantek.com/2011/238/b1/many-ways-slice-url-name-pieces#ud). The [IndieAuth spec](https://indieauth.spec.indieweb.org/#url-canonicalization-p-3) includes a normative reference to WHATWG's URL standard and explains "path component" with a simple example instead of a spec definition:

> As such, if a URL with no path component is ever encountered, it MUST be treated as if it had the path /. For example, if a user provides https://example.com for Discovery, the client MUST transform it to https://example.com/ when using it and comparing it.

So perhaps that would be sufficient for the microformats parsing spec, too?

RFC 3986 lists some [additional normalizations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-6.2) that could be nice-to-have but I'm not sure if they are strictly necessary for parsers:
- make scheme and hostname lowercase
- normalize percent-encoded characters to uppercase ("%3a" versus "%3A")
- decode percent-encoded [unreserved characters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.3)

RFC 3986 also describes [remove_dot_segments](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-5.2.4) to normalize "." and ".." path segments. From a quick check, it appears at least php-mf2, mf2py, and Ruby parsers are all doing this, which makes sense since it's necessary to correclty handle `<base href>`.

**Questions:**
1. Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?
2. What are the simplest steps for this process such that it results in "a) easy for implementers to understand and b) leads to a useful output for consumers" (to quote @Zegnat :))

comment.body: Are paths always `/` if not empty? Even for non-HTTP URLs? IndieAuth is able to short-cut this somewhat as all URLs (except redirect URLs in special cases) are Special URLs, that is, HTTP(S) URLs.

The [IndieAuth spec](https://indieauth.spec.indieweb.org/#url-canonicalization-p-3) includes a normative reference to WHATWG's URL standard and explains "path component" with a simple example instead of a spec definition:

> As such, if a URL with no path component is ever encountered, it MUST be treated as if it had the path /. For example, if a user provides https://example.com for Discovery, the client MUST transform it to https://example.com/ when using it and comparing it.

So perhaps that would be sufficient for the microformats parsing spec, too?

RFC 3986 lists some [additional normalizations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-6.2) that could be nice-to-have but I'm not sure if they are strictly necessary for parsers:
- make scheme and hostname lowercase
- normalize percent-encoded characters to uppercase ("%3a" versus "%3A")
- decode percent-encoded [unreserved characters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.3)

RFC 3986 also describes [remove_dot_segments](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-5.2.4) to normalize "." and ".." path segments. From a quick check, it appears at least php-mf2, mf2py, and Ruby parsers are all doing this, which makes sense since it's necessary to correclty handle `<base href>`.

**Questions:**
1. Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?
2. What are the simplest steps for this process such that it results in "a) easy for implementers to understand and b) leads to a useful output for consumers" (to quote @Zegnat :))

comment.body:
> Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?

I strongly feel like it is normali[sz]ation. Just like how RFC 3986 refers to it. Canonicali[sz]ation to me refers to what [rel-canonical](https://microformats.org/wiki/rel-canonical) is used for, matching the definition from Wikipedia:

> A canonical URL is a URL for defining the single source of truth for duplicate content.

There is no way for a parser like the mf2 parser to figure out that value, since it only has the string to work on. (I would be very much opposed to requiring mf2 parsers to fetch resources, look for [rel-canonical](https://microformats.org/wiki/rel-canonical)s, etc.)

issue.title: Add ARM download URL to mutesync.app cask
issue.body:
After installing with the old cask definition, starting the application showed me a pop-up telling me they had released a separate version for M1/M2 Macs. This updates the cask definition to grab the separate DMGs for ARM and Intel.

I found two different ways casks were doing this. Either by setting an `arch` variable that is used within the download URL, or using the `on_` blocks. I went with the latter as I thought an empty string variable for the Intel URL would just be confusing for the next person to read this definition.

---

After making all changes to a cask, verify:

- [x] The submission is for [a stable version](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#stable-versions) or [documented exception](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#but-there-is-no-stable-version).
- [x] `brew audit --cask --online <cask>` is error-free.
- [x] `brew style --fix <cask>` reports no offenses.

commits.message: Use arch variable in mutesync.app cask

I went with the latter as I thought an empty string variable for the Intel URL would just be confusing for the next person to read this definition.

issue.title: Fix for Composer installation
issue.body:
When `humbug/box` is installed via Composer then
```php
require_once __DIR__.'/../vendor/composer/InstalledVersions.php';
```
(from https://github.com/box-project/box/blob/4.0.2/src/functions.php#L61)

fails as this files exist only when is used as PHAR.

Current behaviour can be seen in the failing check in https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/PHP-CS-Fixer/pull/6554.

comment.body:
In waiting for this PR, I have been able to apply it through [cweagans/composer-patches](https://github.com/cweagans/composer-patches). Installation instructions from scratch:

```zsh
composer config --no-plugins allow-plugins.bamarni/composer-bin-plugin true
composer require --dev bamarni/composer-bin-plugin
composer bin box config allow-plugins.cweagans/composer-patches true
composer bin box require --dev cweagans/composer-patches
composer bin box config --json extra.patches '{ "humbug/box": { "Fix for Composer installation": "https://github.com/box-project/box/pull/695.patch" } }'
composer bin box require --dev humbug/box
```

issue.title: Composer installation does not work when following docs
issue.body:
## Bug report

| Question    | Answer
| ------------| ---------------
| Box version | 4.0.2 (`composer bin all show \| grep humbug/box`)
| PHP version | 8.1.10
| Composer version | 2.4.1
| Platform with version | macOS 12.5.1

Running `vendor/bin/box` will throw an Exception and the application cannot be used after following [the Installation documentation for Composer](https://box-project.github.io/box/installation/#composer).

Quick reproduction steps:
```bash
# Clean folder and composer.json
cd `mktemp -d -t 'box'`
composer init --no-interaction --name zegnat/test
composer config allow-plugins.bamarni/composer-bin-plugin true
# Recommended installation steps
composer require --dev bamarni/composer-bin-plugin
composer bin box require --dev humbug/box
```

#2 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/Console/Application.php(40): KevinGH\Box\get_box_version()

#0 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php(61): KevinGH\Box\{closure}(2, 'require_once(/p...', '/private/var/fo...', 61)
#1 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/functions.php(61): require_once()
#2 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/src/Console/Application.php(40): KevinGH\Box\get_box_version()
#3 /private/var/folders/pv/rtwt6lqx2qn6fh2q3hpdf8m80000gn/T/box.rlqO4ObV/vendor-bin/box/vendor/humbug/box/bin/box(58): KevinGH\Box\Console\Application->__construct()

comment.body:
Just realised there is already a PR for: https://github.com/box-project/box/pull/695. But I could not find an issue?

Feel free to close this in favour of the PR, or keep it around until the PR gets merged so others have an easier time finding it.

pull_request.title: JavaScript runs once, CSS handles a 24 hour animation
pull_request.body:
Somewhere between an interesting experiment and something I wanted to do. No hard feelings if you do not deem it mergable, I will just continue on my fork. There is probably more clean-up that can be done.

This change gets rid of the 4 second JavaScript interval. Instead it generates 24 hour CSS animations once and lets the browser handle it. In the browser profiler this gets rid of rendering and painting steps.

Currently all the elements are added by JavaScript and the animations generated on the fly. Though for even better performance it could have been added straight to the HTML. The only thing JavaScript will always be needed for is to set the animation start time.

This also simplifies the blue hover styling. No more weird blinking in and out of existence for the final coloured rectangle.

Would love to get your opinion on some of these techniques!

issue.title: Define "normalized absolute URL"
issue.body:
This issue is split from https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9 intended to focus only on the process of normalizing URLs when parsing `u-*`.

[Current language](https://microformats.org/wiki/microformats2-parsing#parsing_a_u-_property): 
> return the normalized absolute URL of the gotten value, following the containing document's language's rules for resolving relative URLs (e.g. in HTML, use the current URL context as determined by the page, and first `<base>` element, if any).

One of the simplest things, which https://github.com/microformats/tests/pull/112 is waiting on, is whether to normalize an empty URL path component to "/". @jgarber623 [detailed](https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9#issuecomment-617813565) some specs and software that include this normalization, so I think this would be pretty agreeable among implementers.

@Zegnat raised the concern of defining what we mean by "path component" since parts of URLs have been [renamed over the years](https://tantek.com/2011/238/b1/many-ways-slice-url-name-pieces#ud). The [IndieAuth spec](https://indieauth.spec.indieweb.org/#url-canonicalization-p-3) includes a normative reference to WHATWG's URL standard and explains "path component" with a simple example instead of a spec definition:

> As such, if a URL with no path component is ever encountered, it MUST be treated as if it had the path /. For example, if a user provides https://example.com for Discovery, the client MUST transform it to https://example.com/ when using it and comparing it.

So perhaps that would be sufficient for the microformats parsing spec, too?

RFC 3986 lists some [additional normalizations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-6.2) that could be nice-to-have but I'm not sure if they are strictly necessary for parsers:
- make scheme and hostname lowercase
- normalize percent-encoded characters to uppercase ("%3a" versus "%3A")
- decode percent-encoded [unreserved characters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.3)

RFC 3986 also describes [remove_dot_segments](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-5.2.4) to normalize "." and ".." path segments. From a quick check, it appears at least php-mf2, mf2py, and Ruby parsers are all doing this, which makes sense since it's necessary to correclty handle `<base href>`.

**Questions:**
1. Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?
2. What are the simplest steps for this process such that it results in "a) easy for implementers to understand and b) leads to a useful output for consumers" (to quote @Zegnat :))

comment.body: Are paths always `/` if not empty? Even for non-HTTP URLs? IndieAuth is able to short-cut this somewhat as all URLs (except redirect URLs in special cases) are Special URLs, that is, HTTP(S) URLs.

issue.title: Define "normalized absolute URL"
issue.body:
This issue is split from https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9 intended to focus only on the process of normalizing URLs when parsing `u-*`.

[Current language](https://microformats.org/wiki/microformats2-parsing#parsing_a_u-_property): 
> return the normalized absolute URL of the gotten value, following the containing document's language's rules for resolving relative URLs (e.g. in HTML, use the current URL context as determined by the page, and first `<base>` element, if any).

One of the simplest things, which https://github.com/microformats/tests/pull/112 is waiting on, is whether to normalize an empty URL path component to "/". @jgarber623 [detailed](https://github.com/microformats/microformats2-parsing/issues/9#issuecomment-617813565) some specs and software that include this normalization, so I think this would be pretty agreeable among implementers.

@Zegnat raised the concern of defining what we mean by "path component" since parts of URLs have been [renamed over the years](https://tantek.com/2011/238/b1/many-ways-slice-url-name-pieces#ud). The [IndieAuth spec](https://indieauth.spec.indieweb.org/#url-canonicalization-p-3) includes a normative reference to WHATWG's URL standard and explains "path component" with a simple example instead of a spec definition:

> As such, if a URL with no path component is ever encountered, it MUST be treated as if it had the path /. For example, if a user provides https://example.com for Discovery, the client MUST transform it to https://example.com/ when using it and comparing it.

So perhaps that would be sufficient for the microformats parsing spec, too?

RFC 3986 lists some [additional normalizations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-6.2) that could be nice-to-have but I'm not sure if they are strictly necessary for parsers:
- make scheme and hostname lowercase
- normalize percent-encoded characters to uppercase ("%3a" versus "%3A")
- decode percent-encoded [unreserved characters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.3)

RFC 3986 also describes [remove_dot_segments](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-5.2.4) to normalize "." and ".." path segments. From a quick check, it appears at least php-mf2, mf2py, and Ruby parsers are all doing this, which makes sense since it's necessary to correclty handle `<base href>`.

**Questions:**
1. Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?
2. What are the simplest steps for this process such that it results in "a) easy for implementers to understand and b) leads to a useful output for consumers" (to quote @Zegnat :))

comment.body:
> Is the correct term for this process "normalization" or "canonicalization"?

I strongly feel like it is normali[sz]ation. Just like how RFC 3986 refers to it. Canonicali[sz]ation to me refers to what [rel-canonical](https://microformats.org/wiki/rel-canonical) is used for, matching the definition from Wikipedia:

> A canonical URL is a URL for defining the single source of truth for duplicate content.

There is no way for a parser like the mf2 parser to figure out that value, since it only has the string to work on. (I would be very much opposed to requiring mf2 parsers to fetch resources, look for [rel-canonical](https://microformats.org/wiki/rel-canonical)s, etc.)

comment.body:
Just realised there is already a PR for: https://github.com/box-project/box/pull/695. But I could not find an issue?

Feel free to close this in favour of the PR, or keep it around until the PR gets merged so others have an easier time finding it.

issue.title: Composer installation does not work when following docs
issue.body:
## Bug report

| Question    | Answer
| ------------| ---------------
| Box version | 4.0.2 (`composer bin all show | grep humbug/box`)
| PHP version | 8.1.10
| Composer version | 2.4.1
| Platform with version | macOS 12.5.1

Running `vendor/bin/box` will throw an Exception and the application cannot be used after following [the Installation documentation for Composer](https://box-project.github.io/box/installation/#composer).

Quick reproduction steps:
```bash
# Clean folder and composer.json
cd `mktemp -d -t 'box'`
composer init --no-interaction --name zegnat/test
composer config allow-plugins.bamarni/composer-bin-plugin true
# Recommended installation steps
composer require --dev bamarni/composer-bin-plugin
composer bin box require --dev humbug/box
```
